intro: Chamaesyce proctorii, commonly known as Proctor's sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its unique floral structures and milky sap. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are often surrounded by modified leaves called bracts. Chamaesyce proctorii is adapted to withstand drought and has a low, spreading growth habit.
